prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: There are no time constraints. There are no strong sources in the COSMOS field.

We do not require very high resolution as we do not need to resolve the inner structure of the dust continuum for our science case. However, a 0.8-arcsec resolution is required to resolve the Herschel dust continuum from neighbor galaxies (2-3" away)
Our method follows the ISM measurement with ALMA continuum (Scoville 2013). We ask for a 5-sigma detection in the dust continuum on the Rayleigh-Jeans tail to measure the ISM masses.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal - 919588 CO Band 3 PSB-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO line spectral scan for post-starburst galaxy

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: There are no time constraints. There are no strong sources in the COSMOS field. We do not need to resolve the line for the science case therefore we ask for the most coarse spectral resolution.
The source is ~1kpc. The project is to determine high-resolution

We request the non-standard spectral scan mode as there are two probable photometric redshifts for this source. We require a 5sigma detection for the CO line. The CO line emission is estimated from the L_IR integrated from the Herschel+ALMA band 7 fluxes (Carrilli+2013), and then using a BzK-like CO SLED (Daddi+2014). We request Band 3 in which probes the peak of the CO SLED for both probable redshifts (z~2 and 4). If the source is at z~2, we will detect CO(3-2); if the source is at z~4 instead, we will detect CO(4-3) and perhaps CO(5-4). We used the lowest CO line flux for the sensitivity calculation. We ask for the widest bandwidth to preserve S/N.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to obtain CO line emission and Band 6 dust continuum for a sample of 13 post-starburst galaxies at z=1-4, in order to study why and how they quench star formation. This sample is selected from the COSMOS field as being quiescent in the UV-to-NIR photometry, but are detected by MIPS 24um and Herschel. These properties are consistent with being recently (~200 Myr) quenched galaxies, after star formation is shut off and intermediate-age stars continue to heat the interstellar dust. Our proposed project will be able to shed new light on the physics of quenching through observing molecular gas directly, addressing one of the most intriguing issues in extragalactic studies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
